main event: On December 9, 1952, several witnesses in Odessa, Washington, observed several large white objects hovering in the sky, making abrupt changes in direction and performing sharp turns. These objects were also observed on ground radar scope.
interesting points: Two pilots in an F-94 made visual and radar contact with a large, round white object that was larger than any known type of aircraft.
The object emitted a dim reddish-white light and displayed remarkable maneuvers such as reversing direction almost instantaneously and disappearing at about 3,000 feet.
An attempted contact with local civil air authorities was unsuccessful.
Investigators initially suggested the object could have been an upper air research balloon, but this idea had to be discarded, and the sighting was listed as unknown.
After a review of the evidence, it was suggested that the unknown 'object' may have been the star Sirius caused by atmospheric refraction, producing exactly the phenomenon described.
witnesses: Several witnesses, Two pilots in an F-94
